Title: Fortnite is coming to Android phones â€“ but not through Google Play
Text:
Online shooting game Fortnite: Battle Royale will be available on Android phones this month, but it will not be available on the Google Play store, the official app store for Android devices. Instead, developer Epic Games will make the game available for download via a dedicated installer on its website, avoiding the 30% revenue share that Google would get to host the title on its Play store.



Epic CEO, Tim Sweeney, said the company â€œwants to have a direct relationship with our customers on all platforms where possible ... physical storefronts and middlemen distributors are no longer required. We believe gamers will benefit from competition among software sources on Android.â€

Fortnite made its mobile phone debut on iPhones in April. But Android represents one of the fastest growing video game platforms in the world, with 2.3bn active devices and an estimated 85% share of the smartphone market. A majority of Android users download games and apps via the official Google Play store, which brought in $20.1bn in revenue last year.

â€œFor any developer, going outside the established distribution channels and opting for a direct-to-consumer will be a major challenge, particularly on mobile where getting users to register and share payment details is an issue,â€ said Steve Bailey, a games analyst with IHS Technology. â€œThe strength of the buzz around Fortnite means it should be able to overcome the hurdle of getting core users to download outside Google Play, but it will also need to ensure a smooth and trusted payment process.â€

â€œAvoiding the â€˜store taxâ€™ is a part of Epicâ€™s motivation,â€ said Sweeney. â€œItâ€™s a high cost in a world where game developersâ€™ 70% must cover all of the costs of developing, operating, and supporting their games. Thereâ€™s a rationale for this on console, where thereâ€™s enormous investment in hardware and marketing campaigns in broad partnership with publishers. But on open platforms, 30% is disproportionate to the cost of the services these stores perform.â€



The decision has raised concerns. There is the possibility of Android users inadvertently downloading the game from a fake site, thereby exposing themselves to malware. To access Epicâ€™s installer, users have to switch off a function designed to protect against malicious downloads.

Epic has countered by pointing out that most handsets allow users to customise which sites to give access to, and the open market approach works on PC where there are various third-party stores available. However, other publishers point out that there are already third-party stores on Android â€“ itâ€™s just that most users donâ€™t visit them.

â€œIn most markets it would be brave to ignore Google Play,â€ said Patrik Wilkens, vice president of mobile at Spil Games. â€œThe main disadvantage is that you make it much tougher for your game to be discovered. Amazon, Samsung and a number of other Android stores represent a fraction of the Android user base.â€

It be could that Epic is eyeing a lucrative new market â€“ China â€“ where Google Play does not operate. Having been banned until 2015, games consoles are still struggling to gain a foothold in the country, but over 580 million people play mobile games. Epic Games is partly owned by the Chinese tech conglomerate Tencent, which runs its own highly successful Android stores, giving Fortnite access to a large user-base. Tencent also published Fortniteâ€™s close rival Player Unknownâ€™s Battlegrounds in China, where itâ€™s proving to be a hit.

Meanwhile, there are rumours the Android Fortnite may launch as an exclusive on the forthcoming Samsung Galaxy Note 9 handset, to be announced on 9 August. â€œEpic will have been financially compensated for exclusivity on a platform that only represents a small share of the Android total user base,â€ said Piers Harding-Rolls, director of games research at IHS Technology. â€œFrom Samsungâ€™s perspective, they are using games to position the Note product with key audiences in markets where competition from other Android smartphone companies is escalating.

â€œThere are a cross section of â€˜gamerâ€™ smartphones already on the market targeting enthusiast gamers on mobile platforms. Mobile network operators are also positioning their offerings in the context of gaming, so aligning device marketing with this position makes sense.â€

The success of Fortnite, which is free to download on consoles, PC and smartphones, shows no sign of waning. Released last September, the game is estimated to have made over $1bn in revenue. Over 125 million people have now downloaded the game.

Title: Chicken Connoisseur Elijah Quashie: â€˜Deep down, vegans want to be us!â€™
Text:
Elijah Quashie, better known as The Chicken Connoisseur and now star of new Channel 4 show Peng Life, is almost supernaturally calm. Itâ€™s mid-London heatwave with temperatures hitting 33C, everyone is packed into a hot room at Channel 4â€™s offices and sweating through their clothes, but Quashie sits perfectly still, wearing a coat â€“ A COAT! (a cream-coloured Nike Windcheater as it happens) â€“ and is not even breaking a sweat.

Heâ€™s not fazed by anything, from Star Wars actor John Boyega tweeting that he loved his YouTube series The Pengest Munch (â€œWish I had this growing up! Lmaaoooooooooâ€) to the 175 boxes of trainers taking over at home in Tottenham (â€œI need to lose, like, 70,â€ he says).

In fact, the only thing that gets him heated is chicken â€“ specifically, Nandoâ€™s. Unlike the Love Island rejects who beg the company on Twitter for its legendary Black Card, which gives VIPs free chicken, Quashie is not fussed and wouldnâ€™t accept a card. â€œNandoâ€™s? The last time I ate from there I vomited,â€ he says. â€œI got down to the bone, I was seeing pink bits, and then it all just came up. My body speaks for itself.â€ He was, however, travelling at 90mph in a Lamborghini on the set of Peng Life at the time.

Quashie started his YouTube series The Pengest Munch in 2015, which features detailed reviews of chicken shops in London, from the burger sauce to the seating to the construction of the burgers. Each episode, he visits a restaurant and order the same thing: chips, a chicken strip burger and wings. The worst crimes? Chips that donâ€™t absorb the salt, wings that are pink near the bone and badly constructed burgers with â€œbare lettuceâ€, which will be rated â€œdeadâ€, â€œproblematicâ€ â€œlackingâ€ or a let down for the â€œbossmanâ€ (chicken shop manager).

The most charming part about his reviews (one memorable line: â€œThe burger caught me off-guard, â€™cos it was hench â€¦ but man definitely chewed on a boneâ€) is their earnestness â€“ he genuinely loves chicken shops and just wants them to serve good food. And he doesnâ€™t feel bad about giving bad reviews. â€œI donâ€™t care,â€ he says. â€œIf you put out food that doesnâ€™t bang, that was your decision. And itâ€™s my opinion. I have to keep the integrity of my palette.â€

In 2016, his show went viral, and support from celebs including Radio 1â€™s Charlie Sloth led to TV appearances, getting flown to New York to sample the cityâ€™s chicken shops with A$AP Mob member Bari and more than 41m YouTube views. Thereâ€™s a book, The Pengest Munch: In Search of the Nationâ€™s 50 Favourite Chicken Establishments and heâ€™s in a Samsung phone advert. And now heâ€™s got his own show, Peng Life, where heâ€™s joined by friends Nelson and Wilson to rate and review expensive haircuts, kebabs and watches. Celebs such as Jodie Kidd and Rachel Riley also appear, making you wonder: when was the last time Jodie Kidd ate at Chicken Cottage?

Clearly, the brand was the plan from the start. Calling himself The Chicken Connoisseur, Quashie started a limited company of the same name, and adopted a â€œlookâ€ in videos. â€œA lot of people when they go to restaurants, theyâ€™ll dress up in shirts and ties,â€ he says. â€œI thought when I go [to chicken shops], this will be something special for me, where I dress up in a shirt and tie. I liked the juxtaposition.â€

It might seem as if heâ€™s trying to highlight a class gap and pushing back on the snobby elitism of food critics going for Â£800 meals in Mayfair but, in his world, they simply donâ€™t exist. He doesnâ€™t read restaurant reviews or follow bloggers or influencers on Instagram. Restaurant critics Giles Coren and Jay Rayner are fans. Did he even know who they were when they Tweeted about him last year? â€œNope, and I still donâ€™t.â€ Savage. When he appeared on ITV News he was asked if he â€œever imagined being a food criticâ€. He calmly replied: â€œYeah, that was the plan from the beginning. If I start being a critic, Iâ€™m a critic.â€

He is also unlikely to be backing Jamie Oliver or food campaigners worrying that chicken shops are fuelling the childhood obesity crisis. â€œItâ€™s down to the parents,â€ he says. â€œWhen I was in school there were some hench guys and they [practically] lived at the chicken shop. Iâ€™m sure those kids are eating a lot more Haribo and Pringles and doughnuts than [from] chicken shops.â€

And vegans? â€œNah. Deep down, they want to be us! Theyâ€™re making vegan chicken!â€ Nelson, his co-host, who is sitting in on the interview with twin Wilson, chips in: â€œThe more vegans there are, the more meat there is for us. Keep going with the cause!â€ You canâ€™t fault their logic.

Quashie started because a friend, Elishama Udorok, was doing a BTec (a vocational qualification at college) in media and â€œwas into cameras and stuff. Weâ€™d always go to the chicken shop at lunchtime and come back and debate which one was best.â€ The series, he says, was made for â€œpeople like me, my friends, people who I went to school withâ€.

But taking a web series from online to TV is notoriously difficult â€“ just ask Dapper Laughs. The more successful ones (Broad City, High Maintenance, People Just Do Nothing) worked because their creators retained a lot of behind-the-scenes control, while others failed because their niche audience (Miranda Sings) werenâ€™t willing to follow them to TV. Quashieâ€™s motivation when he started his YouTube channel, he says, was to be his own boss. And because of that, the move to TV sounds as if it has been a difficult one.

â€œIt wasnâ€™t the plan to go to TV. When Channel 4 approached me in April 2017, it was like, meh,â€ he shrugs. â€œBut there wasnâ€™t anything more pressing to do. At the time, I was thinking theyâ€™ve obviously seen and chosen me to host the show because they want what I have made on YouTube to be brought to their channel. Thatâ€™s exactly what they explained it to be â€“ but on set it was a different case. In the end, it turned out to be something I should have seen coming but I didnâ€™t.â€

While making The Pengest Munch, he and Udorok were in total creative control, but with Channel 4, â€œobviously thereâ€™s a director and a producer and theyâ€™ll have scripts and things they think they need to put in there, and Iâ€™m like: â€˜Nah, you guys donâ€™t understand how itâ€™s going to look, itâ€™s going to look better if I do it like this.â€™â€

He adds: â€œIt was a case of: â€˜Boy you have to do this, this is what Channel 4 wants,â€™ and if this my job and I have to do it â€“ all right.â€ He hasnâ€™t seen the first show yet, he says. â€œIâ€™m not nervous, but I just want to see what it looks like. From being on set and [the producer and director] thinking and talking differently [to us] â€¦ Iâ€™m not sure if theyâ€™re going to leave in the best bits.â€

Whatever he thinks of the final product, could Peng Life become a hit, piggybacking on to a trend? Chicken shops have been co-opted by the mainstream in recent years: from rap shout-outs to YouTube series Chicken Shop Date and Drake, Kendall Jenner and BeyoncÃ© endorsing Nandoâ€™s, chicken shops are inescapable. But restaurants are also disappearing as Londonâ€™s working-class areas get gentrified. Chicken shops are becoming, well, Soho House Groupâ€™s Chicken Shops.

â€œPlaces like that, they canâ€™t even make the same chicken â€“ it doesnâ€™t taste as nice. Itâ€™s just not worth the money. Everyone there, they could go to a regular little chicken shop, spend Â£8 and theyâ€™re feeding the whole family,â€ Quashie says.

â€œChicken shops ARE the culture,â€ Quashieâ€™s other co-host, Wilson, says, essential spaces for Londonâ€™s teenagers to hang out. â€œTheyâ€™re as well integrated into communities as a launderette or a dry cleaners,â€ adds Quashie. â€œNo one makes them a big thing, but theyâ€™re always there when you need them. And at the correct ones â€“ not the gentrified ones â€“ for a couple of pounds, you get a pretty decent substantial meal and you canâ€™t get that anywhere else.â€

Quashie is strangely defensive about his age, which is a bit weird, like when your mum gets to a certain age and pretends to be â€œ29 again!â€ every birthday. He wonâ€™t confirm it, saying it â€œisnâ€™t a big deal. I could be 16, I could be 46. It doesnâ€™t make any difference.â€ Clearly he wants to appeal to his core audience of teenagers on YouTube, but records at Companies House list his birthdate as May 1993, making him 25. While he looks incredibly young and could easily pass as a schoolboy, meeting him in person, and having interviewed hundreds of forgettable boybands filled with awkward, fidgeting teenagers, Quashieâ€™s intelligent, fluent, carefully considered answers and steady eye contact is a dead giveaway.

Despite his success, he says heâ€™s â€œnot even closeâ€ to being a millionaire, but YouTube fame means that he now lives a bit like a budget BeyoncÃ©. â€œI get seen and spotted everywhere, I canâ€™t do the normal stuff,â€ he says. â€œGoing to a shop or the post office and not getting hassled, that is a privilege I donâ€™t have any more. Itâ€™s long. If Iâ€™m walking past a school, I get caught.â€

Sometimes when viral stars get TV deals, the moment can pass before the show gets on air, but Peng Life commissioner Becky Cadman isnâ€™t worried as heâ€™s literally stopping traffic. â€œWhen you go out with Elijah, itâ€™s pretty full on. I went to the barberâ€™s with him and this dad who was driving opened the car door, got all his kids out and they were all wanting a picture with him.â€ She hopes that, as well as the â€œ16-35 demographicâ€, parents will want to watch the show with their kids.

But his laidback attitude doesnâ€™t always work: he was criticised in January 2017 when it emerged a rapper who appeared on the webseries had been jailed for assault and was on the sex offenders register. When asked about it, youâ€™d think it would be a good moment for Quashie to distance himself or point out how certain corners of the media are determined to drag down the career of any young black male enjoying success. Instead, he keeps things vague. â€œAt the end of the day, me and my friends still do what we do and weâ€™re still successful with it. [A headline like that] doesnâ€™t take anything away from a good episode.â€

Even though heâ€™s got his own TV show, Quashie says he doesnâ€™t watch TV (apart from Match of the Day) and sees himself returning to YouTube as his next move. â€œChannel 4 wants to rope in my demographic â€“ on to their channel and into TV again. But for me thereâ€™s not much reciprocating. I donâ€™t expect pensioners to be like: â€˜Boom, yeah, Iâ€™m going to jump on YouTube, set up an account and subscribe.â€™â€ He needs a new cameraman â€“ Udorok has got a job at Unilad â€“ and then he plans to go international. â€œI might take a trip around Asia or Africa,â€ he says. Heâ€™ll probably skip having a Nandoâ€™s at the airport, though.

Title: Apple hits $1trn stock market valuation; Bank of England raises interest rates - as it happened
Text:
MP3 players already existed, such as Maldaâ€™s Nomad Jukebox, and they were technically better, with larger hard drives, replaceable batteries, and compatibility with both Windows and Mac (the iPod would take another year to come to Windows). What did Apple have to offer?

With hindsight, the answer is obvious. The iPod looked cool: it had a sleek aluminium shell half the size of its competitors, and a physical scroll wheel that could zoom through the trademark â€œ1,000 songs in your pocketâ€.

By 2003 Appleâ€™s advertising agency, Chiat/Day, had come up with silhouette adverts to promote the iPod. The ads were almost too successful, turning the iPodâ€™s white earphones into such a marker of desirability that the Metropolitan police blamed them for a 26% rise in street robberies in 2005.

The iPod revolutionised Appleâ€™s fortunes, kicking off a five-fold increase in its share price over the following five years, and providing a gateway drug for winning round Windows users to its Mac ecosystem. But it also changed the company on a fundamental level, turning it from a computer manufacturer into a consumer electronics designer.

In January 2007, the company completed this transformation, announcing that it was changing its name from Apple Computer to Apple Inc. That same day, it also announced something else: the iPhone.

Title: Apple shares open 4.4% higher as its value heads towards $1tn - as it happened
Text:
At 54.0, the latest UK manufacturing PMI is the lowest in three months and is a far cry from the levels seen towards the end of 2017. Weaker domestic demand saw new orders fall and the rate of output growth slip to the lowest in 16 months. Interestingly though, demand from abroad hit a six-month high, implying that firms are still reaping the rewards of better global growth, despite the recent moderation in Europe.

But over coming months, life for manufacturers is unlikely to get any easier. The recent escalation in trade tensions is clearly a challenge, but increasingly the biggest headache for businesses is likely to be the threat of a â€˜no dealâ€™ Brexit. This scenario would likely see huge congestion at ports and disruption to supply chains. While we suspect the probability of the UK leaving without an agreement in March next year is relatively low, an agreement may not come until late in the day.

Until then, confidence could begin to fall as uncertainty increases â€“ the latest PMI suggests the degree of positive sentiment is already at a 21-month low.

Having said all of that, todayâ€™s slip in the PMI is unlikely to faze Bank of England policymakers ahead of tomorrowâ€™s decision. Representing around 10% of output, manufacturing is a relatively small part of the UK growth mix. Importantly, the recent data flow â€“ particularly in the much larger service sector â€“ has largely backed up the Bankâ€™s view that the economy has regained poise after the weak first quarter.

For that reason, we think the Bank of England will increase interest rates this week. But the key thing to watch is what the Bank has to say on its next steps. In an ideal world, we think policymakers would like to hike rates again much sooner than markets are currently pricing (towards the end of 2019). But with Brexit uncertainty considerably ramping up, realistically we think the Bank will struggle to raise rates again before the UK leaves the EU next March.

After Thursday, we currently donâ€™t anticipate another hike before May 2019.

Title: Huawei beats Apple to become second-largest smartphone maker
Text:
Huawei overtook Apple to become the worldâ€™s second-largest smartphone seller behind Samsung in the second quarter, the first time in seven years that any contender has managed to split the top two.

Multiple market analysts said that Huaweiâ€™s rise came as the slowdown in China, the worldâ€™s largest market for smartphones, eased, with growing market share in Europe. Huawei failed in its recent bid to launch in the US after government action against companies deemed a security threat.

Despite Apple being historically weak in the second quarter, analysts described the rise of Huawei as significant.

â€œThe importance of Huawei overtaking Apple this quarter cannot be overstated,â€ said Canalys analyst Ben Stanton. â€œIt is the first time in seven years that Samsung and Apple have not held the top two positions.â€

Approximately 351m smartphones were sold globally in the second quarter, down 2% year-on-year due to market saturation, increasing prices, longer replacement rates, reduced mobile phone network subsidies and lack of feature and design innovation, according to data aggregated by the Guardian.

â€œConsumers remain willing to pay more for premium offerings in numerous markets and they now expect their device to outlast and outperform previous generations of that device which cost considerably less a few years ago,â€ Anthony Scarsella from IDC.

Samsung was worst hit by the slowdown of the big three, down 10% year-on-year selling 71.9m smartphones for a 20% share of the market. Huawei raced into the second spot selling 54.2m phones in the quarter, up 41%, for a 15% share of the market. Apple sold 41.3m iPhones, up 1%, for a 12% market share.

â€œThe continued growth of Huawei is impressive, to say the least, as is its ability to move into markets where, until recently, the brand was largely unknown,â€ said Ryan Reith, programme vice president of IDCâ€™s Worldwide Mobile Device Tracker.

Stanton said: â€œHuaweiâ€™s momentum will obviously concern Samsung, but it should also serve as a warning to Apple, which needs to ship volume to support its growing services division.

â€œIf Apple and Samsung want to maintain their market positions, they must make their portfolios more competitive.â€

Tarun Pathak from Counterpoint Research said that Huaweiâ€™s two-pronged strategy using its fast-growing Honor sub-brand to capture the mid-tier segment below Â£500 and its premium Huawei-branded smartphones at the top end, such as the P20 Pro, appeared to be working.

Analysts said that Huaweiâ€™s exclusion from the US has forced it to work harder across Asia and Europe to achieve its growth goals, with its mid-range models proving particularly popular. Data from Canalys showed that Huawei grew it market share in China by 6% to a record 27% in the quarter, where 100m smartphones were sold across the country.

Outside of China, Huaweiâ€™s increasing brand recognition newly allowing it to compete at the top end, but the Chinese market remains key for Huawei as it has come under fire from the US, Australia and other nations over concerns it could facilitate Chinese government spying.

Huawei has denied it facilitates spying and has said it is a private company not under Chinese government control and not subject to Chinese security laws overseas.

China and the US are also embroiled in a trade dispute with both nations imposing tariffs on billions of dollars worth of goods and fighting over technology and patents, which analysts said creates significant uncertainty for all of the major smartphone brands.

Huawei said Tuesday that overall it had 15% higher revenue in the first six months of 2018, steady at levels seen a year ago. Revenue rose to 325.7bn yuan (Â£36.52bn), while operating margin rose to 14%, from 11% a year ago.

Huaweiâ€™s consumer division, which houses its smartphones business, accounted for roughly a third of its total revenue last year. It got half its revenue from its mobile phone network.

Title: Manchester United are missing a trick with JosÃ© Mourinho: the reality show | Marina Hyde
Text:
In 2007, coinciding with the moment David Beckham made his debut for LA Galaxy, I was at their Home Depot Center ground in Los Angeles to watch JosÃ© Mourinhoâ€™s Chelsea compete in something called the World Series of Soccer. Donâ€™t look for this competition â€“ they donâ€™t play it any more. As part of their US summer tour, Chelsea beat LA Galaxy in the last match, though the competition was won on goal difference by â€“ hang on, let me get my reading glasses on â€“ Tigres UANL. Suwon Samsung Bluewings finished fourth.

Before the Galaxy game, Mourinho was asked by an American journalist how much the World Series of Soccer trophy would mean compared with others he had won, including the two Premier League titles and the Champions League with Porto. A pause. Looking the journalist directly in the eye, a smile playing round the corner of his lips, Mourinho declared it would mean just as much to him as all of those â€“ â€œof courseâ€. Obviously, I never speak for the 99% of gentlemen who make up the rest of the sports press pack but my reaction to the moment was the reflection: â€œI do slightly love you, you insolent bastard.â€

It has been so unbelievably and immensely long since I slightly loved Mourinho that even mentioning this vignette feels like exhuming a Paleolithic artefact, turning it over in your hands and thinking: Ugh. This is dirty and I have no idea what it is or ever was.

Anyhow. I think the vague point is that no one could watch Mourinho on Manchester Unitedâ€™s summer tour in the US this year, and think anything other than what an endlessly sour bore he is. If Mourinho once felt like the ironist puppeteer at moments like this, he has long commuted down into the proverbial messy bitch who lives for the drama.

This (if slightly paraphrased) appears to be the verdict of some United players, who are reportedly briefing that they are finding the managerâ€™s behaviour â€œexhaustingâ€ and that he is â€œdragging the whole tour downâ€. His demeanour is certainly weighing down many United fans, who are facing up to the fear it may well be their turn to endure one of Mourinhoâ€™s famous third seasons at a club.

Where will it end? I see the executive vice-chairman, Ed Woodward, has gone to meet Mourinho in Miami, perhaps to thrash out their transfer war in person, but the real puzzle is all the tricks Woodward has been missing. After all, the way Ed seems to see it, United are in the content business, of which â€œactual footballâ€ is only one of the parts. Consider his verdict on the signing of Alexis SÃ¡nchez in January: â€œThe announcement posts generated 75% more interactions than the announcement of the sale of the worldâ€™s most expensive player last summer when Neymar moved from Barcelona to PSG.â€ There was even better news â€“ Jesse Lingardâ€™s recent â€œtakeoverâ€ of Unitedâ€™s Instagram page had generated more than 40m impressions.

If your reaction to this is the Alan Partridge â€œso what?â€ gesture, catch up. Ed is on precisely the same page as Unitedâ€™s managing director, Richard Arnold, who has characterised the club as â€œthe biggest TV show in the worldâ€. A few years ago, the Irish Timesâ€™s Ken Early noted Arnold declaring triumphantly that United had â€œrecently surpassed the social media following of Vin Diesel and were closing on Rihannaâ€.

â€œIf you think about why people watch soap operas,â€ enthused Arnold, â€œitâ€™s what will happen next. That uncertainly is part of what makes sport exciting.â€ All these things considered, Mourinho was the perfect hire â€“ a classic soap diva who creates #content seemingly reflexively.

It seems baffling that these particular executives have failed to monetise Mourinho with some sort of flyâ€‘on-the-wall reality series, particularly now the window may be rapidly closing. For all their postmodernist bluster, perhaps, Unitedâ€™s top brass are still some way behind the proper monsters of unscripted television. They have a lot to learn from, say, Mike Darnell â€“ a US TV executive responsible for a welter of smash hits down the years, as well as controversial shows such as Whoâ€™s Your Daddy? in which an adult adoptee had to pick her biological father from a lineup.

Darnellâ€™s sole regret about that show was that all the outrage generated â€œwas outside the programme â€“ so it doesnâ€™t translate into ratingsâ€. Remember: it doesnâ€™t matter if people think your product is trashy or repulsive or morally bankrupt, as long as you are able to alchemise their anger into ratings gold. (This, you will have noted, is a formula which has now taken the biggest reality star of that era all the way to a highly sought after address in Pennsylvania Avenue.)

Something for Woodward and Arnold to bear in mind on their eternal quest to take things to â€œthe next levelâ€ commercially. If rushed into production now, an unscripted reality Mourinho series would certainly have the ability to reach beyond the productâ€™s existing customer base, or â€œManchester United supportersâ€ as they used to be known. Call it Keeping Up With The KarKrashing One â€“ and give us at least three weeks of unmissable histrionics before its star walks out.

Title: Dani and Jack win the Love Island 2018 final â€“ as it happened
Text:
Weirdly, my most indelible memory is the lacy trousers Rosie wore when when leaving the villa. They were, to quote Wallace and Gromit, The Wrong Trousers.

Anyway, Jack and Dani deserved winners, so we donâ€™t need to storm the palace. Top work everyone, and good night!

Title: Why spend Â£1,000 on a smartphone when you could get one for less than Â£150?
Text:
How do you find the best-value smartphone deal? If you are anything like me, you can be easily overwhelmed by the range of deals on offer â€“ Carphone Warehouse alone lists 77 different pay-monthly plans. But if your old mobile phone has died, or you just dropped it one too many times, donâ€™t be seduced into signing a Â£30-a-month, two-year contract for a Â£500-plus smartphone because, as my recent experience shows, there is just no need to do so.

All you need to do is spend a little more than Â£100 on the latest Chinese-made Huawei (recently rebranded Honor) handset, and grab a Â£7.50-a-month sim-only deal from Tesco Mobile, and all but the most demanding of mobile users will not be able to spot the difference â€“ and save hundreds of pounds.

How did we find out? Well, the Brignall household has just done exactly this, and couldnâ€™t be happier.

Faced with a domestic mobile phone crisis â€“ my daughter Lottie had dropped and smashed her old phone â€“ I went on the hunt for a value smartphone that would do all the usual teen stuff, such as sending emails, using social media, surfing the web and, crucially for her, taking good photos.

Online reviews and the Guardianâ€™s tech guru Samuel Gibbs pointed me to a couple of handsets â€“ one of his favourite budget options, the then Â£169 Moto G6, was still a bit too pricey for us, but he also suggested Huawei/Honor. And the more I read online about its handsets, the more I was convinced this was probably the way to go.

At the time the Â£99 Huawei Y6 looked to be best sim-free deal â€“ meaning my daughter could move her sim card over from the previous phone, and Carphone Warehouse could deliver the next day.

Within hours of its arrival she was declaring it great and, a few months on, it has proved a great choice. Battery life is very good and it does everything a 19-year-old design student has needed.

The camera has been excellent. Its only downside has been its lowly 16GB storage, but this was easily resolved with a Â£15 insertable SD card.

When two months later, my wifeâ€™s four-year-old Windows phone died, we again scouted the market.

On Amazon Prime Day, we bought the Honor 7C for Â£114, down from Â£169. Donâ€™t tell my daughter, but this phone is even better, although some may find the 5.99-inch screen a bit too big.

So far she is similarly happy, and it has left us wondering why people are prepared to pay Â£700 to Â£999 for the latest handsets.

The advantage of buying a sim-free phone â€“ over a contract deal â€“ is that you are not locked in to an expensive provider and can put any sim card in it, at any time. Phones get better and cheaper all the time, so we decided that a three-year contract was no good for us.

Tesco Mobileâ€™s sim deal is not the absolute cheapest, but it is very competitive, and the company offers the best customer service in the industry (winning accolades from Which? and scoring the best in regulator Ofcomâ€™s complaints league table).

For Â£7.50 a month Tesco will give you 1GB of data and 500 minutes of calls â€“ if you sign up for 12 months. It you want 6GB of data a month Tesco will charge you Â£12.50 a month. Tesco uses the 02 network. Giffgaff is also worth looking at, but you canâ€™t go into a store and ask for help.

Carphone Warehouseâ€™s sim-only deals (called ID Mobile) are also cheap â€“ 1GB of data and 500 minutes of calls â€“ for Â£5 a month, on a rolling deal, so you are not locked in.

The other advantage of sim-free is that if a better deal comes along you can switch without the bother of having to get the handset unlocked. Also, if you go on a trip outside the EU where roaming charges can still hit, you can simply put in a local sim.

This week the Techadvisor website, which spends hours comparing handsets, named the Â£469 OnePlus 6 the best phone you can buy right now, beating the Â£999 iPhone X and other rivals. â€œIt is fairly priced, has the best specs you could hope for, looks great and has cameras that can compete with its rivals,â€ it said.

But to me, that still looks way too much. The Huawei P8 Lite is currently Â£129. If you donâ€™t want to go with Huawei/Honor there are other bargains out there â€“ but you wonâ€™t get as much for your money.

Title: Fluffed it! The truth about Build-A-Bear's day of mayhem
Text:
Thursday 12 July should have been a red-letter day for thousands upon thousands of kids, and for their favourite shop, Build-A-Bear Workshop. The company had announced a pay-your-age promotion, so customers in the UK, US and Canada could come in to make their own teddies and pay just a fraction of the normal cost: instead of Â£52 for a top-of-the-range bear, a six-year-old would pay just Â£6. It sounded brilliant.

What Build-A-Bear hadnâ€™t factored in was the devotion of its young customers, and the unending human appetite for getting something cheap. Its shops were overwhelmed with huge queues wanting to take advantage. Police had to be called to help control the crowds outside the Leeds branch. Scores of shops had to close early; thousands of people left without getting in. Even some of those who did left wildly disappointed: one parent told the BBC that she and her children queued for three and a half hours to get into the Derby branch, then spent another two hours waiting to get their bears stuffed: â€œWhen I look back I will probably think, â€˜What have I done that for?â€™ â€“ especially with what I will end up paying for parking,â€ she said. The next dayâ€™s headlines contained the words no executive wants to see describing their business: â€œchaosâ€, â€œcarnageâ€, â€œfiascoâ€.

You might have thought Build-A-Bear would take urgent action to ensure a different outcome when its US stores opened, hours later, but no. Ben Bigalke and his three-and-a-half-year-old daughter Astrid arrived at their local Build-A-Bear Workshop in Minnesotaâ€™s Mall of America at 9.30am â€“ 3.30pm UK time, several hours into the day of disaster. â€œThe area around the store was completely packed with ensconced, almost camped-out customers,â€ he tells me by email. â€œThe line zigzagged through the mallâ€™s first floor and wound its way entirely through the theme park in the centre of the mall to the other side of the mall. It seemed like a quarter-mile-long line, at least. We learned later that people began camping out at 6am and there were probably more than 500 people â€“ maybe 1,000 â€“ in line before the store even opened. We were nowhere near the store.â€

In Minnesota, despite what had already happened in the UK, the events came as a complete surprise to all concerned. The Build-A-Bear store staff didnâ€™t tell customers about how long they might be waiting, or what was happening. â€œI asked a security guard what to expect and they said they were upset by the situation, saying it was unexpected and that they were not prepared or even forewarned that something like that could happen,â€ Bigalke says. â€œThey didnâ€™t have any information about how many hours we could be expected to stay in line for, and I feel like they should have known. There also should have been representatives from the store telling us what was happening and what to expect.â€

Pay-your-age was the first major disaster in Build-A-Bearâ€™s 21-year history, during which time the company has usually been ahead of the game, both as a retailer and a mythmaker. It is rare that a shopping chain has an origin story â€“ its US founder, Maxine Clark, had been shopping with a friendâ€™s children when the little girl commented that they should make their own bears in the absence of anything new in the shops. A lightbulb went on in Clarkâ€™s head. Of course, it wasnâ€™t quite as homespun as that: Clark was an experienced retail executive, who had worked for the May Co department store company and been president of Payless ShoeSource. She knew what she was doing.

The first part of Clarkâ€™s genius â€“ and it was genius â€“ was to anticipate what was to prove the most important shopping development of the internet age before it was de rigueur: experiential retailing. In summer 1998 â€“ a year after Clark set up her first Build-A-Bear Workshop in St Louis, Missouri â€“ Harvard Business Review published Welcome to the Experience Economy, an influential essay that set out the path ahead. â€œFrom now on, leading-edge companies â€“ whether they sell to consumers or businesses â€“ will find that the next competitive battleground lies in staging experiences,â€ wrote its authors. â€œAn experience is not an amorphous construct; it is as real an offering as any service, good, or commodity â€¦ Businesses must deliberately design engaging experiences that command a fee. This transition from selling services to selling experiences will be no easier for established companies to undertake and weather than the last great economic shift, from the industrial to the service economy.â€

This was precisely Clarkâ€™s business plan. Build-A-Bear has an eight-step process: â€œChoose Me, Hear Me, Stuff Me, Stitch Me, Fluff Me, Dress Me, Name Me, and Take Me Home.â€ Everyone who buys from one of Build-A-Bearâ€™s 361 stores or 102 franchised shops â€“ in the US, Canada, the UK, Ireland, Denmark and China â€“ has the same experience. They choose an outer skin from more than 30 options; they select a sound chip to go inside (it can be a prerecorded sound, or one they record themselves); they add in a small satin heart (the part of the process that is the most emotionally rewarding, or manipulative, depending on your point of view); they get it stuffed to â€œjust the right amount of huggabilityâ€; they get the bear sewn up, with a unique barcode for future online participation; they get the fur fluffed; they accessorise it with clothes and extras. They give it a name to be put on a birth certificate and â€œpassportâ€ (I know of one parent who always takes his childrenâ€™s bear passport on business trips, in order to buy something from the local Build-A-Bear Workshop and get the passport stamped). Then they are given the bear in a special carrying case to take home.

â€œI think they did something incredibly clever,â€ says Corin Birchall, founder of the retail consultancy Kerching. â€œYou pick away at the corners and thereâ€™s not actually a lot to it. But it absolutely captured kidsâ€™ imaginations and turned this commodity into a tangibly valuable product. At all retailers across the world, as the internet makes the market more global, a retailerâ€™s job is to add tangible value to their place in the sale journey. I canâ€™t think of another retailer that has added more value to the process. Itâ€™s just incredible how well they can monetise something that seems intangible to an adult. They were ahead of the curve in doing that.â€

And, for kids, the intangible really is something magical. Nicola Huntâ€™s nine-year-old daughter, Jenna, has nine bears and the associated accessories â€“ the bears are from parties and gifts, the accessories (where Build-A-Bear makes a huge chunk of its revenue) bought with birthday money. The number of accessories seems unending, all priced at what appears a reasonable level individually, but capable of mounting up: Â£4.50 for a pair of bear sunglasses, Â£14 for a tent, Â£8 for a sleeping bag, Â£2 for a headband, and on and on and on.

While Hunt feels disquiet at the hard sell given to parents, she admires the way the staff interact with children who visit the stores. â€œI like the actual process of choosing a bear, I like the way they put the heart in and you give it a kiss. But the bears are overpriced, the quality isnâ€™t good and you canâ€™t wash them.â€ Nevertheless, she has seen how important her bears have been to Jenna. â€œShe was very unwell last year and in and out of hospital,â€ she says. â€œOne of the things we did was go to Build-A-Bear and get a bear to go through the process with her. That was really helpful. When she had a drip in her arm, the Build-A-Bear had a drip in its arm. There was something very special about it.â€

The second part of Clarkâ€™s genius was choosing the teddy bear, a toy that has remained fundamentally unchanged since coming to the market 115 years ago. â€œThe teddy bear has become an icon, a symbol of childhood, which is why campaigns aimed at children use the image of a bear â€“ think of Pudsey,â€ says Deborah JaffÃ©, author of The History of Toys. â€œThe teddy was the first really mass-produced soft toy. But it was just chance it was bear â€“ it could have been a dog or a monkey. But a bear is a simple shape to make and doesnâ€™t use much material. Itâ€™s not as complicated as, say, making an elephant.â€

They remain popular, JaffÃ© says, not just because of their simplicity and sweetness â€“ and, truthfully, who does not love a nice teddy bear? â€“ but because animals can stand in for humans in a universal way: bears have neither race nor gender. â€œYou get this in childrenâ€™s book illustrations: in order to get round gender stereotyping or race and ethnicity, itâ€™s easy to use the animal rather than a human form. When you put a human form in, it gets much more complicated. Mattel have had to make Barbie in lots of ethnicities â€“ but you donâ€™t have to do that with an animal.â€

Clark had hit on the perfect combination: a universal product and a new way to sell it, and then to continue to sell. By registering each bear with a unique code before it leaves the store, Build-A-Bear gives its young customers the chance to continue participating â€“ and spending â€“ in the Build-A-Bear experience online once they get home: as well as buying yet more stuff, they can participate in Build-A-Bearâ€™s world. â€œOur website lets children create virtual versions of themselves and their animals and interact with each other online,â€ Clark explained in 2013.

Even before data was such a valuable commodity, Clark had created an idea that meant Build-A-Bear knew more about its customersâ€™ tastes than most toy retailers. As its senior marketing manager for digital explained in 2015: â€œWeâ€™re looking at the data from a macro level to understand whether a particular product resonates with a girl whoâ€™s four years old or 12 years old, and as you market to the mother, how do you continue to tell the mother about additional pets or accessories and fashions? Weâ€™re starting to get into this from a digital perspective with our loyalty members where we have that type of data collection because they chose the option of us continuing to market to them on a one-to-one basis.â€

By the time Clark stepped down as CEO in 2013, the company had generated $5bn (Â£3.8bn) in sales. It also continued to expand its â€œexperiential offeringâ€. As Clarkâ€™s reign drew to a close, it was introducing â€œHyperSound directional audio technologyâ€ into some of its stores, which would let Build-A-Bear run multiple interactive kiosks within its shops, offering a specific audio message to customers. Directional audio is yet another of the techniques used by retailers to try to prolong time in-store and increase the amount they spend. Or, as the website Retail Customer Experience put it: â€œBy using directional audio retailers can create an immersive 3D sound environment confined to a specific area â€¦ Those outside of the zone donâ€™t hear the sound, and for the shopper the experience is similar to wearing headphones, except they arenâ€™t wearing headphones â€¦ The memorable experience delivered via directional audio adds a â€˜wowâ€™ factor that increases the effectiveness of advertising messages, ultimately leading to increased sales.â€Fearing kids were being lost to screens, it partnered with Samsung to place interactive stations in shops, so customers could build their bears without any of the burdensome physical or personal interaction of the traditional experience.

But times arenâ€™t necessarily easy for Build-A-Bear. It made a loss in 2013, when Clark left, before bouncing back into profit. Its 2017 annual report notes that total revenues have declined year-on-year since 2014; last yearâ€™s profits are little more than half its 2014 levels. The report admits one of the main contributors to a consolidated net income increase over the previous year was â€œan increase in gift card breakage revenueâ€. In short, a big chunk of its profit was down to gift cards that had been sold not being redeemed.

The pay-your-age promotion was meant to be the start of a new thrust. By making it open only to members of the Build-A-Bear Bonus Club, it hoped to entice scores of new customers to register. Doubtless they succeeded. Unfortunately, the offer they made was just too good. In the wake of the fiasco, a YouGov poll found that while awareness of the brand had rocketed, that awareness was almost entirely negative.

And, as Birchall observes, the episode was entirely avoidable. First, he says, it is â€œquite alarmingâ€ how badly Build-A-Bear underestimated the level of demand. Whatâ€™s more, the fact that the whole appeal of the shop is based on a time-consuming experience means it does not lend itself to events with acute peaks of traffic, rather than steady flows. â€œI canâ€™t fathom how they could be that far out.â€

At this point, it would be apt to give the last word to Build-A-Bear. I sent them 15 questions, most of which were purely factual, and some specifically about the pay-your-age promotion. After due consideration, the companyâ€™s PR people sent back their response. â€œWe greatly appreciate your interest in this story. We are still reviewing and analysing, so weâ€™re not able to answer most of your questions at this time. That said, we did want to share the press release regarding the Build-A-Bear Count Your Candles program to ensure you had the full details on this program that launched last week.â€

So I go to Brent Cross shopping centre in north London, to the branch hidden away inside the Fenwick department store. There were no customers there on a warm Wednesday morning during term time. Can I speak to the manager, please? Yes, thatâ€™s me. Would you be willing to tell me what it was like to be in charge on the Thursday of pay-your-age? She looks panicked and says she has to call her boss. A couple of minutes later, she returns. â€œWeâ€™re not allowed to talk to anyone. No interviews.â€

At Build-A-Bear, the PR shutters are down. But the bears still sit there in their rows, waiting to be stuffed, fluffed, named and taken home.
â€¢ This article was amended on 25 July 2018. Gift card breakage revenue refers to unredeemed gift cards, not those that are physically broken in half as an earlier version said.

Title: Cracking news: improved smartphone glass twice as likely to survive drops
Text:
Glass-maker Corning has unveiled a new version of its Gorilla Glass used in the majority of smartphone displays, which it says is twice as likely to survive being dropped.



As phones get bigger, and come with glass on the back as well as the front, the potential for smashed devices has increased. While cases have helped, even heavily protected phone screens still end up shattered from impact and then stress from being bent, squeezed or bumped in a pocket or bag.

Gorilla Glass 6 is a new chemically strengthened and highly compressed glass that Corning says has twice the drop protection of its Gorilla Glass 5.

â€œWith breaks during drops being a probabilistic event, the added compression helps increase, on average, the likelihood of survival through multiple drop events,â€ said Dr Jaymin Amin, vice president of technology and product development at Corning.

The new glass survived an average of 15 drops from 1m on to rough surfaces in lab tests compared to 11 for the previous version, meaning it should be more resistant to multiple drops.

â€œGorilla Glass 6 improves upon Gorilla Glass 5 by surviving drops from higher heights, but, more importantly, has been engineered to survive multiple drops,â€ said John Bayne, vice president and general manager for Corning Gorilla Glass.

Corning said Gorilla Glass 6 has similar scratch resistance and other properties to the older glass.

Appleâ€™s current iPhones, Samsungâ€™s Galaxy 9 and the majority of premium smartphones sold in the UK, all use the older Gorilla Glass 5. Corning said Gorilla Glass 6 will be on the market in the next several months, which means top-end smartphones launched in the second half of this year should ship with it.

With multiple iPhones expected in September, along with new Google Pixel smartphones in October and the replacement for the Galaxy S9 in the first quarter of 2019, your next smartphone might not break when you drop it, over and over.

Title: Man who called for attack on Prince George jailed for terrorism
Text:
An Islamic State supporter who called for an attack on Prince George has been jailed for life with a minimum of 25 years for a string of terrorism offences.

Husnain Rashid, of Nelson, Lancashire, called for the four-year-old to be targeted shortly after the prince joined Thomasâ€™s school in Battersea, south-west London, last year.

On 13 October, he posted a photograph of the school superimposed with silhouettes of two masked jihadist fighters. He sent a follow-up message that listed the address, writing: â€œEven the royal family will not be left alone. School starts early.â€

The posts about Prince George were a tiny fraction of Rashidâ€™s output in the 13 months before his arrest on 22 November last year. He also suggested injecting cyanide into fruit and vegetables at grocery stores and poisoning ice-cream in supermarkets, and attacking fans at the football World Cup in Russia.

The 32-year-old initially denied all charges against him, but mid-trial changed his plea on four of the seven counts, admitting three counts of engaging in conduct in preparation of terrorist acts and one count of encouraging terrorism. The Crown Prosecution Service said he had done so only when faced with â€œthe overwhelming weight of evidence against himâ€.



DCI Andy Meeks, the caseâ€™s senior investigating officer, from the north-west counter-terrorism unit, said Rashid had posted 360,000 messages in 150 different forums on Telegram, an online messaging service, between November 2016 and his arrest a year later.



Judge Andrew Lees said the messages, which included exhortations to attack UK football stadiums, the 2017 general election, Wimbledon, the Trafford Centre in Manchester and the BBCâ€™s Proms in the Park, may have been viewed by millions of people.



Sentencing Rashid at Woolwich crown court on Friday, Lees said: â€œThe message was clear: you were providing the name and address of Prince Georgeâ€™s school, an image of Prince Georgeâ€™s school and the instruction or threat that Prince George and other members of the royal family should be viewed as potential targets.â€

Rashid was given a life sentence for each count of engaging in conduct in preparation of terrorist acts, with a minimum term of 25 years. He was sentenced to four and half yearsâ€™ imprisonment for the offence of encouraging terrorism, to run concurrently.

Rashid, who worked as a teacher at the Muhammadi mosque in Nelson, encouraged followers to deploy a variety of weapons, including knives, homemade bombs, poison, chemicals, vehicles and krav maga, a martial art employed by Israeli military forces.

He praised successful terrorist attacks in other countries, writing: â€œLook around you, how many infidels can you reach to and kill, with your car, knife, or even a stone, or poisoning them! â€¦ Go out and take revenge! What are you waiting for? â€¦ We ask Allah to bless you and make you successful.â€

One Christmas he posted a message online wishing people a â€œterror-filled new yearâ€.

The prosecutor, Annabel Darlow QC, said the overarching aim of Rashidâ€™s activities was to provide an â€œe-toolkit for terrorismâ€. He suggested dropping a smoke grenade â€œto cause panicâ€, adding: â€œYou will be enjoying taking them down one after the other #terrorizethekuffar.â€



He also posted: â€œNo need to board trains. Just get to the train station. Then, in the name of Allah, get busy!â€ These words were followed by emojis of a bomb and a knife dripping blood. There was no evidence that anyone acted on his posts.

Rashid went to great lengths to hide his online extremism from the authorities. The encryption on his laptopâ€™s two-terabyte hard drive was so strong that intelligence agencies have been unable to crack it. He used the encrypted Telegram app on three different sim cards and hacked into his neighboursâ€™ internet connections to publish material online.



The vast majority of his activity was carried out on a Samsung smartphone that had no sim card, was on airplane mode and had tape over the camera lens, which police say was counter-surveillance tradecraft.



When officers came to arrest him, Rashid threw the phone out the back door but it landed at the feet of a police officer. He pretended to faint when told he was under arrest.



Rashid lived with his elderly parents in a terraced house in Nelson, a former cotton town. A few doors down, in another house owned by his parents, he urged his online followers to launch real-world attacks.



He came to the attention of counter-terrorism officers in November 2016, about seven months after he is believed to have started posting online, but he was not previously known to the police and had no prior convictions. 



He was in contact electronically with Omar Ali Hussain, a former Morrisons security guard who joined Islamic State in Syria. Rashid asked Hussain for advice on how to join him in Syria, and was advised by Hussain on methods of attack, including bringing down aircraft with lasers.

Four days before his arrest, Rashid made contact with Amaq, the Isis propaganda agency, saying he was â€œdesperateâ€ to join the group in Syria. He saved Â£6,000 through an office job at a garage and applied for a passport in 2016, which police say he planned to use to travel to the war-torn region.



At the time of his arrest, Rashid was working on creating a glossy magazine called Lone Mujahid, the same name as one of his Telegram channels. It was intended to be similar to the al-Qaida publication Inspire, which he distributed along with an Isis-produced magazine.



Two counts of dissemination of a terrorist publication and one of failing to comply with a notice under the Regulation of Investigatory Powers Act were left to lie on file.

Title: Samsung phones sent photos to random contacts, users say
Text:
Samsung is investigating reports that its default text messaging app on the Galaxy S8 and S9 smartphones is sending photos to random contacts without permission.



Users posted complaints on Reddit and Samsungâ€™s support forums about a strange issue that appears to be silently sending photos to random contacts. The Samsung Messages app doesnâ€™t show any sign of sending the photos, meaning the user is completely unaware of the picture messaging.

â€œLast night around 2.30am, my phone sent her my entire photo gallery over text but there was no record of it on my messages app. However, there was record of it on Tmobile logs. Why would this happen?â€ asked one Reddit user.

â€œOddly enough, my wifeâ€™s phone did that last night, and mine did it the night before,â€ said Reddit user Sfkn123. â€œI think it has something to do with the Samsung SMS app being updated from the Galaxy Store. When her phone texted me her gallery, it didnâ€™t show up on her end -- and vice versa.â€

Reddit user Moosan said something similar had happened to them. â€œMy phoneâ€™s battery was super low overnight so maximum power saving had kicked in from a routine I set with Good Lock, and two or three people had been sent photos (just one each, and they were photos I had sent them in the past).â€

While itâ€™s not clear what is causing the random picture messaging, affected users reported receiving an update to the default text messaging app on their Samsung smartphones that enables Rich Communication Services (RCS). This is the long-awaited replacement for SMS that adds modernisation features such as picture messaging, typing indicators and read receipts.

Samsung said: â€œWe are aware of the reports regarding this matter and our technical teams are looking into it.â€

Affected users are encouraged to contact Samsung directly until a fix is issued.

In the meantime, users can switch to another text messaging app, such as Googleâ€™s Android Messages, or disable access to phone storage for the Samsung Messages app.
